QICore_Patients.definition: Submitting Member Organization ID, assigned from Coordinating Center
QICore_Patients.short: Submitting Member Organization ID, assigned from Coordinating Center

QICore_Patients.definition: Unique patient identifier across all admissions, outpatient visits, etc. that does not change over time and is consistent with other data submissions.
QICore_Patients.short: Unique patient identifier across all admissions, outpatient visits,
QICore_Patients.comment:
Priority: High | Notes: Assign and use the same encrypted ID for each patient within and across all tables. The encrypted ID should not contain any PHI (e.g., SSN, DOB, MRN, etc.). Maintain a secure crosswalk of encrypted IDs to actual patient identifiers at each site that crosses all T1D Exchange Quality Improvement initiatives.
Example: The same encrypted IDs should be used on patient's that cross multiple cohort/project data submissions so they may be identified as the same patient.

QICore_Patients.definition: provider id of the diabetes specialist in charge of the patient. This is not the PCP, which is a non-specialist provider. The provider type must one of  'MD, DO, NP'
QICore_Patients.short: provider id of the diabetes specialist in charge
QICore_Patients.comment: Priority: Medium | Notes: Provide this information if it is available

QICore_Patients.definition:
Type of provider id referenced in provider_id

Should be a valid “Type” value listed in the providers file table of acceptable types ('npi', 'pos', 'dea', 'internal').
QICore_Patients.short: Type of provider id referenced in provider_id Should

QICore_Providers.definition:
All provider codes (e.g., facility, physician, educator) will be identified in the data using their assigned National Provider Identification number (NPI), their CMS Provider of Service ID (POS), DEA number, or other nationally recognized active provider code. If no standard code is available, then an Internal Health System ID would be acceptable to submit.
 At least one of the approved IDs must be submitted for each provider and used as the reference value in other data files that have a reference to provider data.
QICore_Providers.short: All provider codes (e.g., facility, physician, educator) will

QICore_Providers.definition:
When using other_id, once it has been reported for a provider, it should not change from data submission to data submission. However, it would be acceptable if an Organization decided to change from reporting the other ID to reporting a standard provider code value from either the 1st, 2nd, or 3rd preferences listed above. During the switch process both codes should be reported to update historical
 values.
QICore_Providers.short: When using other_id, once it has been reported

QICore_Providers.definition: When using an “other_id” for provider id this column is used to specify the type of other id used.
QICore_Providers.short: When using an “other_id” for provider id this

QICore_Providers.definition: Other nationally recognized or Internal Health System ID
QICore_Providers.short: Other nationally recognized or Internal Health System ID

QICore_Providers.definition:
Identifies which provider codes were provided. 
 npi_id: npi,
 pos_id: pos,
 dea_id: dea,
 other_id: internal
QICore_Providers.short: Identifies which provider codes were provided. npi_id: npi,

QICore_Encounters.definition: Assign a unique encounter number for each unique patient encounter. The encounter number must remain consistent across all files which contain that encounter and across all data submissions.
QICore_Encounters.short: Assign a unique encounter number for each unique
QICore_Encounters.comment:
Priority: High | Notes: Epic users: For data elements that are found at the billing record level, please use the HAR value as the
encounter number. For data elements at the EHR record level, please use the CSN value as the encounter
number. A tag ID of TEN0999 will be created to hold the link between the HAR value and all associated
CSN values.

QICore_Encounters.comment: Priority: High if provider_id | Notes: Should be a valid “Type” value listed in the providers file table of acceptable types ('npi', 'pos', 'dea', 'internal').

QICore_Encounters.definition: The status of the encounter record. Encounters should start with a status of planned and then diverge from there to their final status.
QICore_Encounters.short: The status of the encounter record. Encounters should

QICore_Encounters.definition: The actor that is responsible for the current status. This is not the party responsible for changing the status; that would almost universally be the provider. Rather, this is the person responsible FOR the status. For instance if a patient calls to cancel an appointment because they are in the hospital then the status is canceled, the actor is patient, and reason is illness. If the provider reschedules because the offices are closed due to weather then the status is rescheduled, the actor is the provider, and the reason is weather.
QICore_Encounters.short: The actor that is responsible for the current

QICore_Encounters.definition: The reason for the current status; the actor scopes the reason. For instance, an actor of patient and reason is illness would imply the patient was too sick while an actor of provider and reason of illness would imply the provider was sick. Likely exclusively used for canceled or rescheduled encounters.
QICore_Encounters.short: The reason for the current status; the actor

QICore_Observations.definition:

Value should be max 32 characters.

Priority: High | Notes: If no adequate value is provided by the EMR system then the below method can be used to generated the observation_id.

hash( patient_id,
         effective_date,
         effective_time (if available),
         code (LONIC code),
         value)

QICore_Observations.definition:
The Social History Observations define the patient’s 
occupational, personal (e.g. lifestyle), social, and 
environmental history and health risk factors, as well as administrative data such as marital status,
religious affiliation. Race and ethnicity can be reported as observations however they should be properly reported in the patient file
QICore_Observations.short: The Social History Observations define the patient’s occupational,

QICore_Observations.definition:
Clinical observations measure the body’s basic functions such as such as blood pressure, heart rate,
respiratory rate, height, weight, body mass index,
head circumference, pulse oximetry, temperature,
and body surface area.
QICore_Observations.short: Clinical observations measure the body’s basic functions such

QICore_Observations.definition:
Observations generated by imaging. The scope 
includes observations, plain x ray, ultrasound, CT, MRI, angiography, echocardiography, nuclear medicine.
QICore_Observations.short: Observations generated by imaging. The scope includes observations,

QICore_Observations.definition:
The results of observations generated by 
laboratories. Laboratory results are typically generated by laboratories providing analytic services 
in areas such as chemistry, hematology, serology,
histology, cytology, anatomic pathology, microbiology, and/or virology. These observations 
are based on analysis of specimens obtained from the patient and submitted to the laboratory.
QICore_Observations.short: The results of observations generated by laboratories. Laboratory

QICore_Observations.definition:
Observations generated by other procedures. This 
category includes observations resulting from 
interventional and non interventional procedures excluding lab and imaging (e.g. cardiology catheterization, endoscopy, electrodiagnostics, etc.). Procedure results are typically generated by a clinician to provide more granular information about component observations made during a procedure, such as where a gastroenterologist reports the size of a polyp observed during a colonoscopy.
QICore_Observations.short: Observations generated by other procedures. This category includes

QICore_Observations.definition:
Assessment tool/survey instrument observations
(e.g. Apgar Scores, Montreal Cognitive Assessment
(MoCA))
QICore_Observations.short: Assessment tool/survey instrument observations (e.g. Apgar Scores, Montreal

QICore_Observations.definition:

including direct observations made by a clinician and use of simple instruments and the result of simple maneuvers performed directly on the patient’s body.

QICore_Observations.definition:

treatment protocols (e.g. occupational, physical, radiation, nutritional and medication therapy)

QICore_Medications.comment: Priority: High | Notes: FHIR Medication Prescription

QICore_Medications.variable: Should be a valid “Type” value listed in the providers file table of acceptable types.

QICore_Medications.definition:
Core Spec:
01 == patient's
02 == Providers
03 == Encounters
04 == Observations
05 == Conditions
06 == Medications
07 == Care
08 == Claims

Diabetes Spec:
01 == Disease
02 == Insulin
03 == Monitoring
04 == Glucose

QIDiabetes_Disease.comment: Priority: High | Notes: Include on initial encounter only or when requested. Do not send for every encounter.

Priority: Low | Notes: Typical glucose value (mg/dL) for which patient consistently experiences symptoms of hypoglycemia. If range, use high end of range. Prefer blood glucose over sensor glucose value, if available. Do not report mmol/L; to convert, multiply by 18 to convert mmol/L to mg/dL.

Priority: High | Notes: Level 3 (from JDRF consensus document): a severe event characterized by altered mental and/or physical status requiring assistance

OR 

"ICD code
E10.641 – best
 
Also include:
E10.649
E16.0
E16.1
E16.2
E15
 
Technically exclude:
E11.641
E11.649"

Priority: High | Notes: Level 3 (from JDRF consensus document): a severe event characterized by altered mental and/or physical status requiring assistance

OR 

"ICD code
E10.641 – best
 
Also include:
E10.649
E16.0
E16.1
E16.2
E15
 
Technically exclude:
E11.641
E11.649"

Priority: High | Notes: Elevated serum or urine ketones (greater than the upper limit of the normal range) and serum bicarbonate ,15 mmol/L or blood pH ,7.3. Or whatever is routinely documented.
ICD10 code for DKA:
E10.1 - Type 1 diabetes mellitus with ketoacidosis
E10.10 - Type 1 diabetes mellitus with ketoacidosis without coma
E10.11 - Type 1 diabetes mellitus with ketoacidosis with coma
Priority: High | Notes: Will vary by site's acceptance of PRO
Priority: Low | Notes: Will vary by site's acceptance of PRO
Priority: High | Notes: Lab reported serum bicarbonate value in mmol/L associated with a DKA event
Priority: High | Notes: Lab reported serum bicarbonate value associated with a DKA event
Priority: High | Notes: Patient reported date of when a DKA event occurred for patient reported DKA events
Priority: Low | Notes: Documented transition plan for pediatrics patients to be transitioned to adult centre

QIDiabetes_Insulin.comment: Priority: High | Notes: Average number of long-acting insulin injections daily; Include intermediate, long-acting and premixed insulin types. Value=0 (zero) for patients using basal rates exclusively in insulin pump. For variable injection number, take average of range and round down to nearest integer.

Priority: High | Notes: Average number of short or rapid-acting insulin doses daily used to cover carbohydrates and/or correct elevated glucose values. Include only regular and rapid-acting insulin analog doses. For variable injection number, take average of range and round down to nearest integer. Average number of bolus insulin doses per day on download (for pump) and pt report (for MDI)

Priority: High | Notes: Sum of all insulin (in units) administered daily. For variable daily doses, provider to use discretion to estimate average total daily insulin dose over any available period which captures typical range. Ranges not permissible. Round to nearest tenth unit (one decimal point)

Priority: Medium | Notes: Sum of all basal insulin (in units) administered daily. Include long-acting, intermediate-acting, and premixed insulin doses. For variable daily basal doses, provider to use discretion to estimate average daily basal insulin dose over any available period which captures typical range. Ranges not permissible. Round to nearest tenth unit (one decimal point)

Priority: Medium | Notes: Sum of all bolus insulin (in units) administered daily. Include all short-acting (e.g. regular) and rapid-acting insulin doses. For variable daily bolus doses, provider to use discretion to estimate average daily basal insulin dose over any available period which captures typical range. Ranges not permissible. Round to nearest tenth unit (one decimal point)

Priority: Low | Notes: Typical interval (in days) between insulin pump site changes if on insulin pump. For variable intervals, provider to use discretion to estimate interval. For ranges, recommend taking average and rounding UP. Ranges not permissible.
Priority: Low | Notes: Initiated by patient, family or clinic, captured in their EHR system

QIDiabetes_Monitoring.comment: Priority: High | Notes: Average number of BG checks daily. Recommend using average of no fewer than 14 days of blood glucose logs; provider discretion to use average based on fewer days if needed. Recommend using download over self-report when possible. Ranges not permissible. If range documented, take average of minimum and maximum to one decimal point.

Priority: High | Notes: Average number of sensors used in a two week period. Recommend using download over self-report when possible. Ranges not permissible. If range documented, take average of minimum and maximum to nearest integer.

Priority: Low | Notes: Typical interval (in days) between CGM site changes if on insulin pump. For variable intervals, provider to use discretion to estimate interval. For ranges, recommend taking average and rounding UP. Ranges not permissible.

Priority: Low | Notes: Percent of time using CGM during two week period (% time each 2 weeks). Recommend using download over self-report when possible. Ranges not permissible. If range documented, take average of minimum and maximum to nearest integer. Range 0-100.
Priority: Low | Notes: Captured in their EHR system as Yes/No

Priority: High | Notes: Clinic generated value to capture cgm use at the latest visit. This can come from a flowsheet in the EHR or generated by the clinic using the fields that indicate cgm device use

QIDiabetes_Glucose.comment: Priority: Medium | Notes: Mean (average) value of blood glucose values reported in mg/dL. When possible, mean value should be based on glucose values used to determine average blood glucose monitoring frequency. Round to nearest integer. Do not report mmol/L; to convert, multiply by 18 to convert mmol/L to mg/dL.

Priority: Medium | Notes: Standard deviation of blood glucose values reported in mg/dL. When possible, standard deviation should be based on glucose values used to determine average blood glucose monitoring frequency. Round to nearest integer. Do not report mmol/L; to convert, multiply by 18 to convert mmol/L to mg/dL.

Priority: Medium | Notes: Absolute number of elevated BG levels. When possible, count should be based on glucose values used to determine average blood glucose monitoring frequency. For patients with individualized thresholds, report frequency of blood glucose values above patient-specific threshold. If not defined, count all BG all values >180 mg/dL.

Priority: Medium | Notes: Absolute number of low BG levels. When possible, count should be based on glucose values used to determine average blood glucose monitoring frequency. For patients with individualized thresholds, report frequency of blood glucose values below patient-specific threshold. If not defined, count all BG all values <80 mg/dL.

Priority: Medium | Notes: Percentage of elevated BG levels. When possible, percentage should be based on glucose values used to determine average blood glucose monitoring frequency. For patients with different thresholds, report percent of blood glucose values above patient-specific threshold. If not defined, calculate percent of BG values >180 mg/dL. Round to nearest integer. Range 0-100.

Priority: Medium | Notes: Percentage of low BG levels. When possible, percentage should be based on glucose values used to determine average blood glucose monitoring frequency. For patients with different thresholds, report percent of blood glucose values below patient-specific threshold. If not defined, calculate percent of BG values <80 mg/dL. Round to nearest integer. Range 0-100.

Priority: Medium | Notes: Mean (average) value of sensor glucose values. When possible, mean value should be based on glucose values used to determine typical sensor use (frequency or percent time). Recommend using average of no fewer than 14 days of glucose data; provider discretion to use average based on fewer days if needed. Round to nearest integer. Do not report mmol/L; to convert, multiply by 18 to convert mmol/L to mg/dL.

Priority: Medium | Notes: Standard deviation (mg/dL) of sensor glucose values. When possible, standard deviation should be based on glucose values used to determine typical sensor use (frequency or percent time). Recommend using average of no fewer than 14 days of glucose data; provider discretion to use average based on fewer days if needed. Round to nearest integer. Do not report mmol/L; to convert, multiply by 18 to convert mmol/L to mg/dL.

Priority: Medium | Notes: Absolute number of elevated sensor glucose levels. When possible, count should be based on glucose values used to determine typical sensor use (frequency or percent time). For patients with different thresholds, report frequency of sensor glucose values above patient-specific threshold. If not defined, count all sensor glucose all values >180 mg/dL.
 Need to assess how calculated by Dexcom, Medtronic, Glooko, Diasend, and Tidepool. May refine variable once this is identified (e.g. choosing thresholds, combining “buckets”, etc)

Priority: Medium | Notes: Absolute number of low sensor glucose levels. When possible, count should be based on glucose values used to determine typical sensor use (frequency or percent time). For patients with different thresholds, report frequency of sensor glucose values below patient-specific threshold. If not defined, count all sensor glucose all values <80 mg/dL.
 Need to assess how calculated by Dexcom, Medtronic, Glooko, Diasend, and Tidepool. May refine variable once this is identified (e.g. choosing thresholds, combining “buckets”, etc)

Priority: Medium | Notes: Percentage of elevated sensor glucose levels. When possible, percentage should be based on glucose values used to determine typical sensor use (frequency or percent time). Recommend using average of no fewer than 14 days of glucose data; provider discretion to use average based on fewer days if needed. For patients with different thresholds, report percent of sensor glucose values above patient-specific threshold. If not defined, calculate percent of sensor glucose values >180 mg/dL. Round to nearest integer. Range 0-100.

Priority: Medium | Notes: Percentage of low sensor glucose levels. When possible, percentage should be based on glucose values used to determine typical sensor use (frequency or percent time). Recommend using average of no fewer than 14 days of glucose data; provider discretion to use average based on fewer days if needed. For patients with different thresholds, report percent of sensor glucose values below patient-specific threshold. If not defined, calculate percent of sensor glucose values <80 mg/dL. Round to nearest integer. Range 0-100.

Priority: High | Notes: Percentage of glucose levels. When possible, percentage should be based on glucose values used to determine typical sensor use (frequency or percent time). Recommend using average of no fewer than 14 days of glucose data; provider discretion to use average based on fewer days if needed. For patients with different thresholds, report percent of sensor glucose values below patient-specific threshold. If not defined, calculate percent of sensor glucose values between 70 mg/dL and 180 mg/dL. Round to nearest integer. Range 0-100.

Priority: High | Notes: Percentage of low sensor glucose levels. When possible, percentage should be based on glucose values used to determine typical sensor use (frequency or percent time). Recommend using average of no fewer than 14 days of glucose data; provider discretion to use average based on fewer days if needed. For patients with different thresholds, report percent of sensor glucose values below patient-specific threshold. If not defined, calculate percent of sensor glucose values <70 mg/dL. Round to nearest integer. Range 0-100.

Priority: High | Notes: Percentage of low sensor glucose levels. When possible, percentage should be based on glucose values used to determine typical sensor use (frequency or percent time). Recommend using average of no fewer than 14 days of glucose data; provider discretion to use average based on fewer days if needed. For patients with different thresholds, report percent of sensor glucose values below patient-specific threshold. If not defined, calculate percent of sensor glucose values <54 mg/dL. Round to nearest integer. Range 0-100.

Priority: High | Notes: Percentage of elevated sensor glucose levels. When possible, percentage should be based on glucose values used to determine typical sensor use (frequency or percent time). Recommend using average of no fewer than 14 days of glucose data; provider discretion to use average based on fewer days if needed. For patients with different thresholds, report percent of sensor glucose values above patient-specific threshold. If not defined, calculate percent of sensor glucose values >250 mg/dL. Round to nearest integer. Range 0-100.

Priority: High | Notes: Percentage of elevated sensor glucose levels. When possible, percentage should be based on glucose values used to determine typical sensor use (frequency or percent time). Recommend using average of no fewer than 14 days of glucose data; provider discretion to use average based on fewer days if needed. For patients with different thresholds, report percent of sensor glucose values above patient-specific threshold. If not defined, calculate percent of sensor glucose values >180 mg/dL. Round to nearest integer. Range 0-100.
